text: Did you have any questions for myself? No, I was just, yeah kind of wondering do I need any x-rays or like what's what's what on? Yeah, so what it sounds like right now is that you have something called mechanical back pain. It's pretty common and it can be anything from your spinal joints to the discs to the vertebrae or soft tissue or muscle. And a lot of these can be caused by heart activity at work, like carrying heavy things, and then carrying them in like an improper position or something like that. And we dug notes that on his student physical exam, but if after we try some management and treatment plans, it doesn't go away and it persists for more than eight weeks, we do recommend imaging, including an MRI. So in terms of management for our right now, modified activity at work, some short-term bed rest, very very short-term though. And bed rest is only really recommended if you have severe back pain and muscle spasms and you definitely shouldn't be doing that for more than like 24 to 48 hours. Physical activity can help. So I refer all to physical therapy. Our physiotherapy can help. So referral to physical therapy or physiotherapy can help in rehab. And they'll give you some exercises that you can try at home to kind of strengthen those muscles. And then ice and heating packs temporarily can help medications like NSAIDs can help as well with the inflammation.
